column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Press coverage has focused on the fact this is the fastest spinning manmade object ever created , but the aim of the experiment was to research quantum physics .
#Text=How did you end up with this unusual record — was it by accident ?
#Text=From the beginning we wanted to go for a very fast rotating sphere to test the limits of transfer of angular momentum of light .
#Text=The motivation was to explore if we can see [ if ] any anomaly arose as we rotated the particle faster and faster .
#Text=The hope was to develop an experimental platform that would allow testing the boundary between classical and quantum physics .
#Text=That this worked better than expected was a happy accident .
#Text=How was the sphere manufactured , and how long did it take ?
#Text=The spheres are produced by mixing three chemical compounds together ( CaCl2 , MgSO4 and K2CO3 ) until the mixture becomes transparent .
#Text=This happens in about 5 to 10 minutes and results in birefringent spherical vaterite crystals of 4.4 micrometer in diameter .
#Text=How long did the sphere take to reach 600 million revs per minute and break up ?
#Text=The whole process takes about 10 – 20 minutes .
#Text=It all depends on how fast we evacuate the vacuum chamber .
#Text=If we do it too fast we risk [ losing ] the micro-gyroscope from the trap .
#Text=With regard to the sphere breaking up :
#Text=This is a working hypothesis that we are not able to prove yet .
#Text=What we observe is that the signal corresponding to the rotating sphere disappears at 600 million RPM .
#Text=We need further measures to verify if the sphere breaks up or if its motion is perturbed and it escapes in some slingshot or other motion .
#Text=Could the high speeds attained be taken as evidence against quantum friction , as the sphere simply kept getting faster until it broke apart ?
#Text=This is a very interesting question .
#Text=The particle keeps getting faster and faster until the signal disappears , however , just before this happens we observe that the slope of the acceleration changes .
#Text=This could be seen as a signature of " quantum friction " but we need to look more closely .

column1: #Text=Alternatively , it might be a consequence of the sphere deforming at such high rotation rates .
#Text=The experiment failed to conclusively prove quantum friction , but did it provide any evidence to support the theory ?
#Text=Spheres of vaterite manufactured for the experiment , viewed through a scanning electron microscope Image : A. Di Falco .
#Text=The main goal of the experiment was not to prove or disprove quantum friction but to develop a tool that might be useful to carry out these studies in the near future .
#Text=Though the micro-gyroscope that we studied sounds like a simple system its behaviour and interaction with the laser beam is very complex .
#Text=In order to use this experiment to prove or disprove quantum friction
#Text=it is first necessary to completely understand and model its complex behaviour .
#Text=We need therefore more extensive experimental studies and more precise simulations .
